title: Patient-Reported Symptom Assessment and Early Chemotherapy Discontinuation in ... - medRxiv

summary.text: More frequent completion of patient-reported symptom assessments post chemotherapy initiation was associated with a lower risk of early discontinuation due to toxicity in gastrointestinal cancer patients.
After adjusting for demographic, clinical covariates, and time-varying bias, completing post-initiation assessments was linked to a 30% reduction in the cumulative risk of early discontinuation.

The study suggests that increasing patient engagement through regular symptom monitoring may help identify those at higher risk of treatment interruptions, allowing for timely interventions to improve outcomes.
